rows.text_1:
How to **CONNECT?**

Join your child in their world!
rows.media_transcript:
Joining your child in their world means giving them your full attention, and letting them lead. You don’t need a lot of time - even 10 minutes a day can make a big difference. Here’s how:

Make time to spend with your child one-on-one. Try to minimise distractions and interruptions.

Join your child in their world by getting down on your child’s level. Sit close to them to make it a shared experience.

Let your child decide what to play and how to play. Don’t try to change what they are doing or instruct them. Instead, follow their lead. 

During the activity, observe and listen. Pay attention to what your child is doing or saying. Be curious about what they might be thinking and feeling.   

Respond to what your child is doing with enthusiasm and praise. You could say: I see you are enjoying playing with these blocks. Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall!

Joining your child in their world and giving them your full attention helps them feel close and connected to you. This helps you build a strong relationship with your child. A strong relationship with you will help them to have healthy relationships with others in the future.

rows.text_1: Let’s see what happens when we don’t let our child to take the lead:
rows.text_2: Let’s play with the blocks together, Lonwabo.
Who can build a taller tower?
No, you are doing it wrong. Use the big blocks for the bottom and the small blocks for the top.
Where are you going? Why don’t you want to play together?

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Yes, the father is choosing what to play and how to play, instead of letting his son take the lead.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Looking at the story, we can see that the father is actually the one who is choosing what to play and how to play.
rows.quiz_2_question: How does Lonwabo feel when his father says he is doing it wrong?
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: He feels unhappy and deflated. He might not want to play together again.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Looking at the story, we can see from Lonwabo’s face that he feels unhappy, and then walks away.

rows.text_1: What could the father have done differently?
rows.media_transcript:
Why did the son feel discouraged and why did he walk away? 

Because the father was being critical and tried to change what his son was doing. 

Connecting with our children is not about telling them how they should be playing or what they are doing wrong. By following your child’s lead, showing that you are paying attention and responding with praise, you make your child feel important and connected to you. This builds their confidence and sets them up for success.
rows.text_2: Good question! He could have let his child lead and used praise instead of criticism.

rows.text_1:
Looking for a quick and powerful connection activity? 

A great way to connect with your child is to look at a book together.
Here’s how to connect during book activities:
rows.media_transcript: As you go through the book, notice what your child is interested in and talk about it. So, if your child is looking at the picture of the sandwich, you could say: “Look, he is eating some bread. What do you think is on the bread? What do you like to eat on your bread?”
rows.text_2: As you go through the book, notice and respond to what your child is interested in.
Let your child set the pace. They might want to spend a long time talking about one page or move on quickly to the next page. Follow their lead.

rows.media_transcript:
Instead of saying “no!” or “that’s wrong!”, use praise and positive responses to encourage your child to keep learning.

If your child says something that’s wrong (like pointing to an apple and calling it a tomato) you don’t need to say “how can you think that?!” or “that’s wrong!”. 

Instead, you can ignore the mistake and respond with the correct name, saying: “That’s an apple. It’s red and round like a tomato, but it’s an apple”. Your child will learn more if they don’t feel criticised or discouraged.
rows.text_2: Always try to respond to what your child is saying in a positive and enthusiastic way.
